title: If You Can’t Make Predictions, You’re Still In A Crisis
summary:
Key ideas:
- Over 60% of psychology experiments failed to replicate in a recent study
- Failure to replicate is a normal part of how science works 
- Scientists must figure out under what conditions a phenomenon is true
- Publication bias, experimenter effects and statistical malpractice contribute to the replication crisis in psychology

Key learnings:
- Failure to replicate is not necessarily a cause for alarm in science
- Psychology needs to reconcile differences in replication conditions in an informed Bayesian way 
- Claims of scientific understanding in psychology are weaker due to the likelihood of a phenomenon being true only under certain conditions 

Key questions:
- What factors contribute to the failure to replicate in psychology experiments?
- Is it possible to reconcile replication differences in an informative Bayesian way? 
- How can we solve the replication crisis in psychology, and what are we up against?
